name: f19f3
probTex:
Assume that $f$ and $g$ are analytic near a point $a\in\mathbb{C}$ with $f(a)=g(a)=0$ and $f'(a),g'(a)\neq0$. Prove that
\[\lim_{z\to a}\frac{f(z)}{g(z)}=\lim_{z\to a}\frac{f'(z)}{g'(z)}=\frac{f'(a)}{g'(a)}.\]
solnTex:
We know that, as an analytic function which takes $a$ to 0, $f(z)=(z-a)^kr(z)$ where $k\geq1$ and $r$ is analytic. Moreover, $k$ must be 1 and $r(a)\neq0$ because $f'(a)\neq0$, so $f(z)=(z-a)r(z)$. Likewise $g(z)=(z-a)s(z)$ for some analytic $s$ with $s(a)\neq0$. Then
\[\lim_{z\to a}\frac{f(z)}{g(z)}=\lim_{z\to a}\frac{(z-a)r(z)}{(z-a)s(z)}=\lim_{z\to a}\frac{r(z)}{s(z)}=\frac{r(a)}{s(a)}.\]
Also $f'(z)=r(z)+(z-a)r'(z)$ and $g'(z)=s(z)+(z-a)s'(z)$, so $f'(a)=r(a), g'(a)=s(a)$, and
\[\lim_{z\to a}\frac{f'(z)}{g'(z)}=\lim_{z\to a}\frac{r(z)+(z-a)r'(z)}{s(z)+(z-a)s'(z)}.\]
Now $r'$ and $s'$ are analytic so, in particular, are continuous, and $r(a)$ and $s(a)$ are still nonzero, so this limit reduces to $\frac{r(a)}{s(a)}=\frac{f'(a)}{g'(a)}$ also.
